summary: The video is a continuation of a tutorial series aimed at walk planning using software tools and GPS. Neil Bauers, the narrator, guides viewers on how to convert Google Earth walk plans for GPS use, focusing on using the GPSBabel software.

events_list.video_caption:
The video begins with a title screen displaying text in a typewriter-style font on a plain white background. The text reads "Ipswich Ramblers Walk Planning Software Tools and GPS Neil Bauers nbauers@btinternet.com PART TWO." This introductory slide sets the stage for the content that follows, indicating that the video will discuss software tools and GPS for walk planning, authored by Neil Bauers, with contact information provided.

The scene then transitions to a Google Maps interface, showcasing a satellite view of a residential area with a prominent church labeled "St. Michael and All Angels." The map includes a disclaimer about the track logs, emphasizing the importance of public rights of way and safety. The user interface elements, such as the search bar and navigation tools, are visible, indicating an interactive map environment.

Next, the video shifts to Google Earth, displaying a similar satellite view of a residential area with a large green field in the center. The field is outlined with a blue line, and a coordinate marker is placed at the top of the field. The user interface includes a sidebar with various options and a list of places, suggesting the use of the software for detailed walk planning. The video demonstrates the process of adding a new place, as indicated by the "Add" option being highlighted in the sidebar.

The video continues with the Google Earth interface, showing the same satellite view of the residential area with the large green field outlined in blue. The sidebar on the left lists various places, including "2010, Wayne, RA," "2010, Wayne Plans," and "2010, Tenterife New Map." The user interface elements, such as the search bar and navigation tools, remain visible, emphasizing the interactive nature of the software. The video highlights the "Add" option in the sidebar, indicating the process of adding a new place to the list.

Finally, the video shows the Google Earth interface with the same satellite view of the residential area and the large green field outlined in blue. The sidebar on the left lists various places, including "2010, Wayne, RA," "2010, Wayne Plans," and "2010, Tenterife New Map." The user interface elements, such as the search bar and navigation tools, are still visible. A yellow hand cursor is seen hovering over the green field, indicating user interaction with the map. The video demonstrates the process of adding a new place, as indicated by the "Add" option being highlighted in the
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a voice welcoming listeners to part two of a talk, introducing the topic as "walk planning for Ipswich Ramblers", mentioning "software tools and GPS", and then giving contact details. The voice then summarizes part one, stating that they created a walk plan in Google Earth, which is now being saved, and emphasizes the importance of changing the file type to KML. A statement is made that "most GPS receivers don't understand that". The speaker suggests that "GPS Babel is brilliant for this".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases the process of downloading and installing GPSBabel software, a tool for GPS data conversion and transfer. It begins with a web browser displaying the GPSBabel website, highlighting its features and compatibility with various operating systems. The user navigates to the download page, where the latest releases for Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux are listed, along with their respective download counts. The user initiates the download of the Windows version, and the browser shows the download progress. The next frame displays the "Downloading now..." page, encouraging users to support the project financially through Google Checkout or PayPal donations. The user proceeds to the setup wizard, which guides them through the installation process, including selecting the installation location and confirming the installation. The video concludes with the GPSBabel application window open, showing its interface and options for file input and output, indicating the software is ready for use. Throughout the video, the background remains consistent with the website's blue theme, and the user's actions are focused on navigating the download and installation process.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker discussing a free download, noting that there are versions for Windows, Apple Mac, and Linux. He decides to grab the Windows version and save it.  The sounds of installation commence. He says he's going to do a "completely standard installation," joking that he's read "very carefully" the agreement. The sounds indicate the installation finishes with an icon appearing on the desktop.  Then he says "and there it goes" indicating the installation completed. The speaker then states, "and there it is running" and the clip ends.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying the GPSbabel software interface, which is used for converting GPS data between different formats. The interface is predominantly blue with white text, and a pop-up window titled "GPSbabel Preferences" is visible, listing various file formats such as "Alan Mag 500 tracklogs (L4)" and "Bushnell GPS Waypoint File Download." The user is seen interacting with the software, selecting different options and formats from the dropdown menus. The background of the screen features a webpage with a message thanking users for supporting Google, and a note about the page not being refreshed since 2011. The user's actions suggest they are configuring the software settings, possibly to prepare for a GPS data conversion task. The video captures the user's interaction with the software, highlighting the process of selecting and configuring file formats within the GPSbabel program.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker expressing frustration with the large number of formats, saying, "I have a problem because there are hundreds and hundreds of formats." He then suggests a solution, advising the listener to navigate to "file preferences formats" to remove unnecessary formats and add back the desired ones. Throughout the speech, there is a consistent sound of background noise, possibly indicating movement, potentially related to the speaker.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying the GPSbabel software interface, which is used for converting GPS data between different formats. The main window of the software is visible, with a blue background and a white dialog box in the foreground. The dialog box is titled "GPSbabel Preferences" and contains a list of various GPS data formats, such as "Geocaching.com Log," "Garmin Training Center," and "Global Mapper." The user is seen interacting with the dialog box, selecting different formats from the list. The main window of the software also displays a message thanking the user for supporting Google, along with a URL for downloading the software. The user is seen selecting a file format, "Garmin Headsource.gyb," from the dialog box. The video provides a clear view of the software's interface and the user's interaction with it, highlighting the functionality of GPSbabel in managing GPS data formats.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker mentioning "Google keyhole markup" and identifies it. He states his intention to add "Garmin GDB" because of some Garmin software and then mentions "GPXXML". The speaker explains that most GPS software will understand the GPX format, including his own GPS receiver. He then concludes that they now have three choices, which is more manageable.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interacting with the GPSBabel software on a computer. Initially, the user is seen navigating through the software's interface, selecting input and output file formats, and choosing a file to convert. The user then proceeds to select a folder on the computer, likely containing the file to be converted. The interface displays a message indicating that the download is in progress, with a thank you note and a prompt to support the project financially. The user continues to interact with the software, selecting a file and initiating the conversion process. The video concludes with the software displaying a message indicating that the translation was successful, and the user appears to be satisfied with the outcome. Throughout the video, the user's actions are focused on utilizing the GPSBabel software to convert files, with the interface providing clear instructions and feedback on the process.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing KML, or Keyhole Markup Language, then proceeds to describe the process of choosing and copying a file, later mentioning "Ramblers plans." He then explains how to paste the file, remove quotes, and change the file extension to GPX. The speaker emphasizes that the translation was successful and that he can load the GPX file into his GPS receiver. Concluding the recording, the speaker says, "So we finished with that."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying a webpage titled "Downloading now..." from GPSBabel.org, thanking users for downloading the software and providing links to support the project through Google Checkout and PayPal donations. The webpage also includes a message about the project's development and testing. The scene transitions to a file explorer window on a computer, showing various folders and files on a D: drive, including "44 South Road," "2015-15 Temefle," "Bam," "Congo Pics," "Clock," "Downloads," "Edgals," "Audio," "Navi and st," "Map," "PDF," "Video," "Geoshash," "Houses," "Ian Bauers," "Ian Virgin," "Keep-software," "OSM," "Rambles," "SCS," "web," and "VS_RVEXP51N4_emu.CAB." The file explorer window is then shown again, this time with the "Devices and drives" section visible, displaying the D: drive with 52.58 GB of free space out of 111 GB, along with other drives such as a DVD RW drive and USB drives. The video concludes with a view of the "Devices and drives" section, highlighting the D: drive and other connected devices, with the cursor hovering over the D: drive.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker setting the scene, mentioning a "file explorer on the screen" and a "GPX file," indicating a tech-related context. He plans to copy the file. There's a slight pause as he realizes he's unplugged the Garmin device, followed by sounds of plugging something in, possibly a USB connector. He then speaks again, explaining the device should be recognized soon. While waiting, he mentions a photo he took earlier, before silence.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a Garmin eTrex 20 GPS device, displaying its screen and backside, highlighting its rugged design and the Garmin logo. The screen shows the Garmin logo and a USB icon, indicating connectivity. The backside features a black strap with the Garmin logo and a mounting hole. The scene transitions to a split-screen view, with the left side showing the GPS device's screen and the right side displaying a map on the device's screen. The map indicates a walking route of 0.4 miles, with labeled locations such as "St Michael's All Angels Primary School" and "The Green." The map also shows a red line marking the walking path and a scale of 300 feet. The video then shifts to a computer screen displaying a file explorer window with various folders and drives, including a USB drive labeled "USB Drive (3)" and a DVD drive labeled "DVD Drive (2)." The final frame shows the computer screen with the Alt+Tab key combination visible, indicating a transition between windows. The video provides a detailed look at the Garmin eTrex 20 GPS device and its functionality, as well as a glimpse into the computer's file management system.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating he's using a Garmin eTrex 20, pointing out the GPS cable plugged in. He mentions a walk he uploaded earlier, referencing the cricket pitch, and indicates the ability to follow the walk live on the screen. Finally, he remarks, "And there it is."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying a file explorer window, showing various folders and files related to GPS and Garmin software. The user navigates through the folders, opening a 'Current.gpx' file, which is a GPS track file. The scene transitions to a webpage titled 'Downloading now...' from GPSBabel.org, where the user is prompted to support the project financially through Google Checkout or PayPal. The user then returns to the file explorer, opening the 'Current.gpx' file in Google Earth, which displays a map with a marked route and various points of interest. The user interacts with the map, zooming in and out, and exploring different areas, including a detailed view of a specific location with a marked route and points of interest. The video concludes with the user continuing to explore the map in Google Earth, highlighting the detailed geographical features and the marked route.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing how to paste a walk file into the Garmin folder, specifically the GPX subfolder, and replacing a previous file. He explains that after loading this file into a GPS receiver, one can then follow the walk.  He then discusses reversing the process, referring to a "GPX current" file that can be loaded into Google Earth. He then provides steps on how to find the Garmin GPX current file in order to see recent walks and gain insights into his darker secrets.  He concludes by saying he went for a random short walk.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interacting with Google Earth, navigating through various locations and editing paths. Initially, the user zooms in on a rural area with fields and a river, then moves to a different location labeled "Raven's Green" near "Great Bentley." The user draws a path through a forested area, encountering a pop-up message about editing limitations. The user then edits a path in a forested area, with a pop-up window titled "Google Earth - Edit Placement" appearing, allowing adjustments to the path's color, width, and style. The user continues to edit the path, with the interface displaying options for adding a description, style, color, and width. The video concludes with the user zooming out to show the entire path within the forested area, with the interface displaying various saved locations and paths. Throughout the video, the user's actions are focused on editing and navigating paths within Google Earth, with the interface providing tools for customization and exploration.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with the clicking of a mouse. A male speaker discusses loading a recorded walk track into Google Earth for processing, mentioning a walk in Wayland Wood and some issues with Google's handling of GPX files from sat-nav receivers. He suggests needing additional software for format conversion, speaking in an informative tone. The clip then abruptly cuts back to the sound of a mouse click.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screenshot of a computer screen displaying Google Earth, where a blue line traces a path through a forested area, indicating a walking or hiking route. The interface shows various options and tools for navigation and exploration, with a timestamp of "2015-10-13 8:37 pm" visible. A pop-up window appears, asking if the user wants to save unsaved items in the "Temporary Place" folder, with options to "Save," "Discard," or "Cancel." The scene transitions to a different view within Google Earth, showing a residential area with houses, roads, and a church labeled "St. Michael and All Angels." The video then shifts to a disclaimer text on a black background, explaining the purpose of the track logs and the importance of public rights of way. The final frames display a white screen with text reading "Ipswich Ramblers Walk Planning Software Tools and GPS Neil Bauers nbauers@btinternet.com PART TWO," indicating the title and author of the presentation or document. The video concludes with a black screen, suggesting the end of the presentation or a transition to another segment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with speech, the speaker seemingly marking a task as complete, stating, "Okay, that's job done." They then mention discarding something. Following this, the speaker says "Thank you for listening" and "Good planning." Then, a low, droning electronic tone sound is heard.
